bibl.title: Qasr Ibrim in Lower Nubia: Cultural Interaction at the Southernmost Roman Limes.
bibl.note: [Introduction.] - The Romans and Lower Nubia: 1. What came before: Black pharaos and Macedonian rulers; - 2. From conflict to contact (30 BC-AD 298); - 3. Importing Roman Egypt, integrating Roman Nubia; Meroitic north and Meroitic south. - A new frontier and new policies: 4. Turmoil on the southern frontier, 298-ca. 450; - 5. Blemmyes and other barbarians. - Christianizing Nubia, ca. 450-652: 6. An epoch of change; - 7. Christianity and power. - The Limes forever: 8. Bishops and builders; - 9. The Nubian dam; - 10. Exchange and infringement. - Conclusions.

bibl.title: Qasr Ibrim, Between Egypt and Africa. Studies in Cultural Exchange (NINO Symposium, Leiden, 11-12 December 2009)

bibl.seg: Jacques van der Vliet, Qasr Ibrim in Lower Nubia: Cultural Interaction at the Southernmost Roman Limes.

J. van der Vliet & J.L. Hagen (edd.), with the assistance of C.H. van Zoest & L.E. van de Peut, Qasr Ibrim, Between Egypt and Africa. Studies in Cultural Exchange (NINO Symposium, Leiden, 11-12 December 2009) = Egyptologische Uitgave. 26 (Leuven, 2013) pp. 1-22.

[Introduction.] - The Romans and Lower Nubia: 1. What came before: Black pharaos and Macedonian rulers; - 2. From conflict to contact (30 BC-AD 298); - 3. Importing Roman Egypt, integrating Roman Nubia; Meroitic north and Meroitic south. - A new frontier and new policies: 4. Turmoil on the southern frontier, 298-ca. 450; - 5. Blemmyes and other barbarians. - Christianizing Nubia, ca. 450-652: 6. An epoch of change; - 7. Christianity and power. - The Limes forever: 8. Bishops and builders; - 9. The Nubian dam; - 10. Exchange and infringement. - Conclusions.
